newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK activists in island protest at Japan consulate.
newsitem.headline: HK activists in island protest at Japan consulate.

text.p: A dozen demonstrators stormed Japan's consulate on Wednesday as tensions simmered over rival sovereignty claims to a group of islands in the East China Sea, but they left when police arrived.

Waving banners with the slogans "Down with Japanese militarism", "Protest against Japanese government interference in the Diaoyu isles", the protesters chanted slogans in the lobby of the consulate in the heart of Hong Kong's financial centre.
"No one has been arrested, no injury. They were just yelling, chanting slogans. When police arrived...they left," a police spokesman said.
But consulate spokesman Tsuguyoshi Hada said a consulate employee and a security guard were injured.
The group, led by Democratic Party lawmaker Tsang Kin-shing, was evicted by police promptly after the consulate called for help, Hada said.
Tsang had just returned from a protest trip to the islands, which China calls the Diaoyus and Japan the Senkakus.
On the voyage he and other activists, including some from Taiwan, pierced a Japanese maritime cordon and planted flags on one of the uninhabited rocky islets on Monday.
Japan has claimed the islands since 1895 and refuses to admit that sovereignty is open to discussion. China has claimed sovereignty over them for centuries. Taiwan also claims them.
The Japanese consulate has asked for extra police protection in recent weeks and has appealed to Japanese living in Hong Kong to take precautions.
"Although there are no concrete threats, it's probably better for you to be careful," is the message being given to Japanese residents in Hong Kong, Hada said.
The protest movement has spiralled in Chinese communities in East Asia since a Japanese right-wing group erected a lighthouse and planted flags on the islands, northeast of Taiwan, in July.

On Tuesday Xinhua news agency's Hong Kong office, Beijing's de facto embassy, said it had received a letter from Japanese rightists threatening the life of Chinese people in Hong Kong, Taiwan and China.
Police said on Wednesday they were monitoring the situation closely after the official's claim, but no such attacks had been reported.
Hong Kong Governor Chris Patten urged Xinhua to give police a copy of the threatening letter for investigation.
He also said there was no justification for breaking into the Japanese consulate.

"I recognise how strongly feelings run on the particular issue, which has been the focus of demonstrations, and I will always defend absolutely people's right to express their views, to demonstrate their views, with this qualification: they must always act within the law," he said.

"If people today have not acted within the law then that lets down the cause which they believe in. And if there has been a break-in to diplomatic premises there is absolutely no justification for it whatsoever," he added.
Patten said the police would make sure the consulate was properly protected if it emerged such protection became necessary.
Hada, the Japanese consulate spokesman, called the incident "regrettable".

"The Consulate General of Japan strongly requests all parties concerned to express their opinions in a peaceful and legal manner," said Hada. "The Japanese consulate has formally requested that the Hong Kong government takes appropriate action with regard to this event."
